sections.heading: Welcome to Česká Republika
sections.text: Czechia, officially the Czech Republic, is a Central European country known for its rich history, stunning architecture, and vibrant culture. Its capital, Prague, is famous for landmarks like Prague Castle and Charles Bridge. Czechia boasts a strong tradition in arts and literature, with notable figures such as Franz Kafka and Antonín Dvořák.

sections.heading: Name and Etymology
sections.text: The name “Czech” comes from the Czech people, a Slavic ethnic group. "Czechia" was adopted in 2016 as a shorter, official name for the country.

sections.heading: Geography
sections.text: Czechia is a landlocked country bordered by Germany, Poland, Slovakia, and Austria. It features diverse landscapes, including mountains and plains, and is divided into three historical regions: Bohemia, Moravia, and Silesia.

sections.heading: Capital City
sections.text: Prague (Praha) is the capital city, known as "the City of a Hundred Spires" for its many historic churches and towers. Key attractions include Prague Castle, Charles Bridge, and the Old Town Square.

sections.heading: Language
sections.text: The official language is Czech, a West Slavic language that uses the Latin alphabet. It is a vital part of national identity and is taught in schools.

sections.heading: Population
sections.text: Czechia has a population of about 10.5 million, primarily ethnic Czechs, with small minority groups. It boasts a high standard of living and a strong education system.

sections.heading: Religion
sections.text: Czechia is predominantly non-religious, including atheists and agnostics, but they are historically predominantly Catholics. Today only 10-11% of Czechs are Catholics. Other religions include Protestantism, Orthodox Christianity, and Judaism.
